perturbation.explanation: By giving Excite the right to modify the payment schedule at its sole discretion and without advance notice, this contradicts standard contract law principles which require mutual agreement for contract modifications. This lack of mutuality makes the payment terms unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text:
Payments of shared gross margin will be due to Excite within thirty (30) days of the end of each calendar quarter in which
                   the revenue is recognized by Sponsor.
perturbation.changed_text: Payments of shared gross margin will be due to Excite at Excite's sole discretion, and Excite is not required to provide a date.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment terms to 'at Excite's sole discretion' removes any fixed deadline, potentially violating laws that require clear payment schedules and prompt payment for services or revenue sharing. This also creates uncertainty and could be deemed unconscionable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Definiteness of Terms; Unconscionability

perturbation.original_text:
Excite may, upon no less than thirty (30) days prior written notice
                   to Sponsor, cause an independent Certified Public Accountant
                   to inspect the records of Sponsor reasonably related to the
                   calculation of such payments during Sponsor's normal business
                   hours. The fees charged by such Certified Public Accountant in
                   connection with the inspection will be paid by Excite unless
                   the payments made to Excite are determined to have been less
                   than ninety percent (90%) of the payment owed to Excite, in
                   which case Sponsor will be responsible for the payment of the
                   reasonable fees for such inspection.
perturbation.changed_text: Excite may, at any time and without notice, inspect the Sponsor's records and Sponsor shall not deny the request. All costs will be at the Sponsor's expense, regardless of the findings.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 30-day notice period and shifting all inspection costs to the Sponsor, regardless of accuracy, can be seen as an unfair and potentially unenforceable contract term. A reasonable notice period is expected under good faith and fair dealing principles, and the cost allocation shift without regard to the audit's findings may be deemed unconscionable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing; Unconscionability
